The framers of our Constitution were intelligent enough to understand that they could not foresee the political challenges and social conditions of future American society. That slavery would eventually be abolished seemed likely to them, but they chose not to act but to defer. that fact in and of itself shows that they viewed the Constitution as a dynamic political construct and living document. The constitutional amendment process itself demonstrates that they never intended their views to be the final word. Do strict constructionists really wish to argue that Americans of African-American descent should have the rights of 3/5 ths of a person, because that was the written intention of our nation's founders?

Are conservatives really complaining that the 14th amendment has been abused? I have never found anything in the writings of our Constitution's authors to even remotely suggest that they thought private companies should be accorded the constitutional rights of persons.

It is complicated. Either you believe that democracy means equal protection under the law or you don't. Enough of the obfuscations.

As to your last question: no, of course not.
But to this issue: show anywhere in the constitution that marriage is limited to opposite sex couples.
This is not a change in the constitution, but an equal application of it.

I find myself torn between happiness at positive social reform, and sorrow over idea that the Supreme Court can, as the article's head line suggests, make anything at all a right. The right of people to marry whom they wish: A very good thing.  The Supreme Court's misuse of the 14th amendment to make it so: A very bad thing. The constitution is indeed a living document, designed to evolve with the culture. The means - the only licit means - for this evolutionary change in the constitution is amendment. Not reading a completely unintended meaning into an old amendment, but rather the passage of new amendments which reflect our changing understanding of justice. So I find myself happy for those who will receive benefit from this, but saddened for the violence done to our system of law. And yes, I realize that there have always been those who have felt the constitution should be interpreted in this loose way, that it's meaning is different for each generation. I disagree. Consider  this: If the decisions being made, which are  based more on what people believe to be right than on the specifics of the constitution, were being made by people whose views were radically opposed to your own sense of morality, would you be equally happy?

The object of the original Restatements was “to present an orderly statement of the general common law.” Restatement of Conflict of Laws, Introduction, p. viii (1934). What is the question the referendum will ask the voters? Or, will it be two referenedums.

There are two possible questions that I suppose can be made into one:

Should Greece choose harsh austerity or should Greece leave the Euro - check only one box: ___ Austerity ____ Leave Euro.

Both have great potential consequences.

Now as a matter of politics you might add these questions:

Should Greece seek closer financial ties with Russia? ___ yes, ___ no

Should Greece lease large Air and Naval bases on Crete to Russia in exchange for Cash and cheap energy? ___ yes, ___ no

Should Greece leave NATO? ___ yes, ___ no

I would not place a question as to whether or not Greece would stay in the European Economic Community or even the EC or even the EU, presumably successor creations of each other, but perhaps still legally on the books, because Greece will need access to the European market to sell whatever they can.

What Tim Kane hears from Spanish professors is just what I read in the occasional NYT article about EU workings.  More and more legislation and (unelected) regulation is being issued from the center.  Unlike in the U.S., the regulators are not subject to effective control by elected representatives, neither a President nor a Parliament.

At this moment, the EU and particularly the Eurozone will reveal more than any words can affirm of deny what Europe's leaders believe and what Europe is. Of course, EU isn't perfect; no political union is. The Eurozone is fundamentally flawed in ways that are painfully inequitable for many of its poorer members and that must ultimately proved fatal, unless remedied. But EU's strength, it ability to right its wrongs, reform its errors, and recover from crisis is, if at all, in its ideas of democratic, just, equitably and mutually prosperous, and at least competently administered union. The Eurozone was a bold progress in that union, perhaps too bold, but it was always meant to adhere to the foregoing ideas.

But what the Eurozone has become is a quasi state that protects profligate lenders from the consequences of their bad loans by insisting that the governments of debtor nations become debt collectors, collecting ruinous payments from their people in the form of taxes, trade deficits, and/or spending cuts; it has become a set of rules and institutions to enforce those rules which enshrine the trade surpluses of the rich nations at the expense of the poor nations

At this moment, Greece, through PM Tsipras, says no. Tasipras says that either Greece shall have an equitable restructuring of her debts that permits her people decent lives and the prospect of a hopeful and prosperous future. Or if he is simply to be a tax collector for Greece's creditors, (cont.)

he must at least have Greeks' consent to do so.
